p:
The vast divergence in terrestrial carbon flux projections from Earth System Models (ESMs) reflects both the difficulty of observing and modeling biogeochemical cycles, as well as the uncertainty in the response of ecosystems to rising atmospheric CO 2
1, 2 . Rising atmospheric CO 2 can generate a fertilization effect that initially increases the rates of photosynthesis and terrestrial CO 2 uptake
10 . However, this fertilization effect may saturate in the future, due to a maximum ecosystem photosynthesis rate being achieved, or because of other limiting factors, such as nutrient limitation
11 .
